author: Tito S. Talao
title: Abueva, pals face Slovenia today
text:
Oct. 15 Basketball , Featured no comments 
At the same time the Philippine Basketball Association was deliberating yesterday the likelihood of doing its part in sending him and Gilas Pilipinas to the Olympic Qualifying Tournament next year, Alaska’s Calvin Abueva was prepping up his Manila North squad for war today in the FIBA 3×3 World Championship in scorching Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates. 
After finishing second to world champion Novi Sad Al Wahda in the FIBA Manila Masters leg last August at Robinson’s Place in Ermita, Manila North, which dethroned Terrence Romeo and the Manila West team in the semifinals, earned a ticket to the World Tour and has been bracketed in Pool D with Doha of Qatar and Kranj of Slovenia. 
Manila North takes on the Slovenians at 1:20 p.m. (9:20 a.m. Manila time) and the Qataris at 3:10 p.m. (12:10 p.m. Manila time). 
In Pool A are Novi Sad of UAE, Rio of Brazil and Vilnius of Lithuania. Pool B brought together Ljubljana of Slovenia, Santos of Brazil and Denver of the United States, while in Pool C are Trbovlje of Slovenia, Kolobrzeg of Poland and New York Harlem of USA. 
Teams in the same group play each other with the top two moving to the knockout quarterfinals. The last four advance to the semifinals where the winners dispute the title. 
Novi Sad ruled the 2014 World Tour in Sendai, Japan where it defeated Saskatoon of Canada in the final. Manila West, which defeated Doha in the Manila Masters final, finished fiftn behind Kranj and Bucharest. 
With Abueva are Aces teammate Vic Manuel, who made a last-minute decision to join the team, Mahindra’s Karl Dehesa and Talk ‘N Text rookie Troy Rosario. 
“Laban lang kami para sa bayan,” vowed Abueva. “Basta kami, ibibigay namin lahat ng makakaya para sa Pilipinas.” Abueva etched his name in the history books of FIBA 3×3 basketball last year by making a dramatic comeback from the hospital where he had earlier brought his wife who was about to give birth to their fourth son. 
With undermanned Manila North trailing Xinzhuang in the quarters, Abueva burst into the Fashion Hall of SM Megamall, barricading his car at the venue’s entrance, and saved the day for his team to the deafening roar of the packed five-story balcony. 
Manila North would lose to Doha in the semis, but the defeat was avenged in the final by Manila West with Romeo, KG Canaleta, Rey Guevarra and Aldrech Ramos. 
Abueva and Co. couldn’t be denied this time, however, as their strong second place finish qualified them to the World Tour and an anticipated rematch with Doha.
